In the opening chapters of this book, we noticed that, in every-
day discussions, much is taken for granted and left unsaid. In general, there is no
need to state points that are already a matter of agreement. In contrast, philoso-
phers usually try to make underlying assumptions explicit and then subject them
to critical examination. Still, even for the philosopher, something must trigger an
